attachments.title: 12 Freelancers Tell You The Best Thing About Being a Freelancer
attachments.text: For me, there are three things that I thing are the best thing about being a freelancer.

elements.text: Added!

text: <@UUY24HLUW> for your first question I do regret not putting the stat in the title... when I wrote the title originally I didn’t put it in because Hubspot already has a similar case study, but they don’t go into other stats like why list posts are better to update, etc. As for how much time it took... well a lot! Mostly because I didn’t really know what stats I wanted to look at. For example, I was hoping to see some kind of correlation between updating pieces and back links, but there really wasn’t any so I ended up throwing it out. However I was able to finish the entire thing in one week (research and writing the post). So while it’s time consuming, it’s definitely doable! Your third question is one I’m still working on... I think it really depends on the case study/data study you’re doing. I usually just try to use free data available. Try to start with the problem you want to explore and work backwards. For example, my new obsession is what I can do to attract more links. So what I think I’ll probably do is gather like 20 of the top marketing websites and put the URLs in Ahrefs. Then I’ll sort them by most linked to pages and look for any correlations I can. So I’m not really looking to create one stat but rather analyzing a problem and seeing what trends surface. I actually did a round up post of a few content marketers asking how they’ve created original data and some of them went deep into tools they use for data pieces. You’re welcome to check it out here: <https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2020/03/free-original-data-content/|https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/2020/03/free-original-data-content/>

attachments.title: 7 Free Ways to Get Original Data for Your Content
attachments.text: Using original data in your content can deliver big results at no additional cost. These seven examples show you how – Content Marketing Institute
attachments.fallback: Content Marketing Institute: 7 Free Ways to Get Original Data for Your Content

text: Thanks <@U01D0FSPDV4>! And yes 100% agree <@UJG24P8P6>

elements.text: Thanks
! And yes 100% agree

text: Yeah, I agree with <@UJE6FLEFJ> and <@UV5TB6FQW>'s answers here. I think 20% of your blogs bring you 80% of the traffic. So, you will need to update only the high-performing ones regularly. And, for the rest, you can try and consolidate them. Companies like Ahrefs have about 200+ blogs, which they keep updating every now and then. In fact, you can even have a content audit to see where you stand and I would strongly recommend taking out the non-performing ones. This way, you will narrow down on your niche.

and

Companies like Ahrefs have about 200+ blogs, which they keep updating every now and then. In fact, you can even have a content audit to see where you stand and I would strongly recommend taking out the non-performing ones. This way, you will narrow down on your niche.

text:
<@UL2E0QVB3> i might check for a correlation between a change in _traffic_ and a change in _rankings_. if rankings are stable but traffic dropped, it's more likely to be:

1. seasonal (or event-related)
2. a change in how results appear (e.g., new SERP feature)
3. cannibalization from another channel (e.g., a boost in paid spending eating organic clicks)

and a change in
rankings

cannibalization from another channel (e.g., a boost in paid spending eating organic clicks)

text: I do not have to sit through pointless meetings.

elements.text: I do not have to sit through pointless meetings.

text:
Hi, all. I'm looking for an agency that can take an already written piece of content — say, a great blog post with lots of interesting stats — and use it to create a really nice interactive landing page. Basically, a great design team that would allow myself and my content team to publish really cool landing pages, ebooks, etc. without having to loop in internal design resources that are already fully scoped.

Any suggestions? Agencies you're worked with in the past that you've loved?

elements.text:

I'm looking for an agency that can take an already written piece of content — say, a great blog post with lots of interesting stats — and use it to create a really nice interactive landing page. Basically, a great design team that would allow myself and my content team to publish really cool landing pages, ebooks, etc. without having to loop in internal design resources that are already fully scoped.

Any suggestions? Agencies you're worked with in the past that you've loved?

text: I love the feeling of control I get as a freelancer. My wife and I spent ~15 months traveling abroad and working remotely, and we frequently spent 5-7 days visiting family with minimal impact on productivity since I can work from anywhere.

elements.text: I love the feeling of control I get as a freelancer. My wife and I spent ~15 months traveling abroad and working remotely, and we frequently spent 5-7 days visiting family with minimal impact on productivity since I can work from anywhere.

text: They are a little pricey but have you checked out Ceros? It’s not an agency but rather a web app made exactly for stuff like this

text: QQ - Do you usually find that changing the structure/template of a piece of B2B content without changing the message/ideas can dramatically change it’s performance (SEO, conversion)?

elements.text: QQ - Do you usually find that changing the structure/template of a piece of B2B content without changing the message/ideas can dramatically change it’s performance (SEO, conversion)?

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

I think structure may matter less than optimizing for keywords and phrases in all the right places, updating the content, improving the quality or depth of the content, and improving the CTAs (how they’re written, the graphics, or the offer itself). So if changing the template or structure also includes those things I listed, then yes you could likely change rankings and conversions without changing the original idea or message. But I don’t think moving sections around or reformatting would have an impact without some of things I listed. Hope this helpful. (That list is how I first approach optimizing older posts for SEO or conversions)

elements.text: I think structure may matter less than optimizing for keywords and phrases in all the right places, updating the content, improving the quality or depth of the content, and improving the CTAs (how they’re written, the graphics, or the offer itself). So if changing the template or structure also includes those things I listed, then yes you could likely change rankings and conversions without changing the original idea or message. But I don’t think moving sections around or reformatting would have an impact without some of things I listed. Hope this helpful. (That list is how I first approach optimizing older posts for SEO or conversions)

text: Thanks!

text: Hey everyone *what are your thoughts on content marketing for B2C companies*? Have you seen it used early on to build an audience, do you think it’s better used once you reach a certain size, does it depend on the product (specialized vs. commoditized)? Curious to know what you think since a lot of content marketing I’ve seen discussed here and otherwise has been focused on B2B content marketing, specifically B2B SaaS.
